8.29: And Moshe said to Pharaoh, “Behold, I go out from your presence and I shall pray before LORD JEHOVAH and he will remove the swarms from Pharaoh and from his Servants and from his people tomorrow, only do not let Pharaoh continue to deceive without sending out the people, and we will sacrifice to LORD JEHOVAH.”
8.30: And Moshe went out from the presence of Pharaoh and he prayed before LORD JEHOVAH.
8.31: And LORD JEHOVAH did according to the word of Moshe, and he removed the swarms from Pharaoh and from his Servants and from his people, and not even one was left.
8.32: And Pharaoh hardened his heart also at this time and he did not send the people away.

9.1: And LORD JEHOVAH said to Moshe: “Go to Pharaoh and say to him, ‘Thus says LORD JEHOVAH, God of the Hebrews, “Send out my people and they will serve me.
9.2: And if you choose not to send away, and until now you are holding onto them,
9.3: Behold, the hand of LORD JEHOVAH will be on your cattle that are in the wilderness, on the horses, and on the donkeys, and on the camels, and on the oxen, and on the sheep, a plague that is very severe.
9.4: And LORD JEHOVAH will separate between the animals of Israel and the animals of the Egyptians, and no animal of the house of Israel will die, not even one.’”
9.5: And LORD JEHOVAH gave the time that LORD JEHOVAH would make this response in the land: “Tomorrow.”
9.6: And LORD JEHOVAH made this response the day after it, and all beasts of the Egyptians died, and of the beasts of the house of Israel, not even one died.
9.7: And Pharaoh sent and he saw that not even one of the beasts of Israel died, and the heart of Pharaoh was hardened and he did not send the people out.
9.8: And LORD JEHOVAH said to Moshe and Aaron: “Make full your handfuls of the ashes of a furnace, and let Moshe scatter them before the face of Heaven, before the eyes of Pharaoh.
9.9: And there will be dust in all the land of Egypt and there will be on the children of men and upon beast, abscesses of blisters that multiply in all the land of Egypt.”
9.10: And they took the ash of a furnace and they stood before Pharaoh, and Moshe scattered it toward the sky before the eyes of Pharaoh and there were abscesses of boils, and it flew among the children of men and among beasts.
9.11: And the Sorcerers were unable to stand before Moshe because of the abscesses that multiplied among the Sorcerers and in all Egypt.
9.12: And LORD JEHOVAH hardened the heart of Pharaoh and he did not listen to them, as LORD JEHOVAH had said to Moshe.
9.13: And LORD JEHOVAH said to Moshe, “Arise at dawn and stand before Pharaoh and say to him, “Thus says LORD JEHOVAH, God of the Hebrews: ‘Send out my people and they will serve me.
9.14: Because at this time I am sending my plague on your heart and upon your Servants and upon your people, so that you may know there is none like me in all the Earth.
9.15: Because now I stretch out my hands and I strike you and your people with slaughter and you will be destroyed from the Earth.
9.16: And moreover it is for this that I raised you up so that I shall show you my power and so that My Name will be proclaimed in all the Earth.
9.17: And until now you hold onto the people and you do not desire to send them away.
9.18: Tomorrow at this time I shall bring very strong hail that is unlike any in Egypt from the day that it was built even until now.
9.19: And now send and gather your animals and everything that you have in the wilderness, every son of man and the animals that are found in the field, and upon those not assembled within a house the hail will fall and they will die.
9.20: He who was in awe of the word of LORD JEHOVAH from the Servants of Pharaoh gathered his Servants and his animals into the house:
9.21: And he who did not take the word of LORD JEHOVAH to his heart left his Servants and his animals in the field.
9.22: And LORD JEHOVAH said to Moshe, “Lift your hand before the face of Heaven and there will be hail in all the land of Egypt, on children of men and upon beast and upon all grass that is in the field that is in the land of Egypt.”
9.23: And Moshe lifted his staff before the face of Heaven, and LORD JEHOVAH gave a noise, and hail and fire was walking on the ground, and LORD JEHOVAH brought down the hail on the land of Egypt.
9.24: And hail was coming down, and flaming fire was inside the hail; it was very severe, the likes of which there had not been in all the land of Egypt from the day that it became a nation.
9.25: And the hail beat on all the land of Egypt, all that is in the wilderness, from children of men and unto beast, and the hail destroyed all grass of the field and it broke all trees that were in the field.
9.26: Only in the land of Gashan where the children of Israel were dwelling did the hail not fall.
9.27: And Pharaoh sent and he called Moshe and Aaron and said to them, “I have sinned this time. LORD JEHOVAH is righteous and I and my people are wicked.
9.28: Pray before LORD JEHOVAH and there is much room before him that there will not be the voice of God and hail, and I shall send you out and you will not stay any longer!”
9.29: And Moshe said to him, “When I go out from the city, I shall stretch out my hands to LORD JEHOVAH; the noises shall depart and hail will fall no more, so that you may know that the Earth is LORD JEHOVAH’s.
9.30: And I know you and your Servants, that until now you do not worship before LORD JEHOVAH God.”
9.31: And the flax and barley were destroyed because the barley root was struck and the flax was bent.
9.32: And the wheat and the rye were not destroyed because they were late growing.
9.33: And Moshe went out from the city from the presence of Pharaoh, and he spread his hands to Heaven to LORD JEHOVAH and the noise departed, and hail and rain did not beat on the ground.
9.34: And Pharaoh saw that the rain and hail and the noise departed, and he continued to sin, and the heart of Pharaoh and of his Servants was hardened.
9.35: And the heart of Pharaoh was hardened and he did not send out the children of Israel, just as what LORD JEHOVAH sent by the hand of Moshe.

10.1: And LORD JEHOVAH said to Moshe: “Go to Pharaoh, because I have hardened his heart and the heart of his servants so that I would do these signs among them:
10.2: And so that you would narrate before your son and the son of your son what I have done in Egypt and the signs that I have done among them, and you shall know that I AM LORD JEHOVAH.”
10.3: And Moshe and Aaron came to Pharaoh and they said to him, “Thus says LORD JEHOVAH, God of the Hebrews, ‘How long will you choose not to fear me? Send my people out and they will serve me.
10.4: And if you choose not to send my people out, behold, tomorrow I shall bring the locust upon your entire border:
10.5: And it will cover the face of the land, and a son of man will be unable to see the land and it will eat the rest of anything that the hail has left for you and it will eat of all of the trees, those that have budded to you in the field:
10.6: And your houses will be filled and the houses of your servants and the houses of all Egyptians which your fathers and the fathers of your fathers did not see in this way, from the day that they have been on the Earth and until today’”, and they turned and they went out from before Pharaoh.
10.7: And his Servants said to Pharaoh, “How long will we have this scandal? Send away the men and they shall serve LORD JEHOVAH their God. Do you not know that you have destroyed Egypt?”
10.8: And they returned Moshe and Aaron to Pharaoh, and he said to them, “Go serve before LORD JEHOVAH your God, but who and what are going?”
10.9: Moshe said to him, “With our young and with our old, we shall go; with our sons and with our daughters, with our sheep and with our oxen we will go, because it is a feast of LORD JEHOVAH for us.”
10.10: And he said to them, “LORD JEHOVAH shall be with you in this way when I have sent you and your little ones, but see that there is no harm against your persons.
10.11: Not in this way; go now you men and serve before LORD JEHOVAH, because it is rest that you seek”, and they took them out from before the presence of Pharaoh.
10.12: And LORD JEHOVAH said to Moshe: “Lift your hand over the land of Egypt for the locust and it will come up over the land of Egypt, and it will eat the grass of the land and everything that the hail has left.”
10.13: And Moshe lifted his staff over the land of Egypt and LORD JEHOVAH brought out the wind of dry heat over the land all that day and all night. Dawn came and the wind of dry heat carried the locust.
10.14: And the locust came up on all the land of Egypt and it destroyed within the entire border of the Egyptians; it was very severe and there was not a locust plague like it before it, neither shall there be one like it after it.
10.15: And it covered the face of all the land and the land grew dark and it ate all the grass of the land and all fruit of the trees that the hail had left and it did not leave a leaf in a tree, neither grass in the field in all the land of Egypt.
10.16: And Pharaoh hurried to call Moshe and Aaron and he said to them, “I have sinned against LORD JEHOVAH your God and against you.
10.17: Also now forgive my injury this time and pray before LORD JEHOVAH your God and he will remove from me this death.
10.18: And Moshe went out from before Pharaoh and he prayed before LORD JEHOVAH.
10.19: And LORD JEHOVAH turned and he brought the west wind that was very strong and it carried the locust and cast it into the sea of Reeds, and there was not left even one locust in all the border of the Egyptians.
10.20: And LORD JEHOVAH hardened the heart of Pharaoh and he did not send out the children of Israel.
10.21: And LORD JEHOVAH said to Moshe: “Lift your hand to Heaven and there will be darkness over all the land of Egypt, and it will darken darkness.
10.22: And Moshe lifted his hand to Heaven and there was darkness and thick darkness in all the land of Egypt three days:
10.23: No man saw his brother, and no man arose from his place for three days, and for all the children of Israel there was light among their dwellings.
10.24: And Pharaoh called Moshe and said to him, “Go serve before LORD JEHOVAH, only leave your flocks and your oxen, and also your little ones will go with you.”
10.25: Moshe said to him: “Also you shall give into our hand sacrifices and offerings and we will sacrifice to LORD JEHOVAH our God.
10.26: Also our beast will go with us and there will not remain of us even one hoof here, because we are taking it to serve before LORD JEHOVAH our God, and we do not know what we will serve before LORD JEHOVAH when we arrive there.”
10.27: And LORD JEHOVAH hardened the heart of Pharaoh and he did not want to send them away.
10.28: And Pharaoh said to Moshe, “Go from my presence; beware that you do not again appear before me, because in the day that you appear to me, you will die!”
10.29: Moshe said to him, “You have said well; I shall not see your face again.”

11.1: And LORD JEHOVAH said to Moshe: “I shall bring one more plague on Pharaoh and upon the Egyptians, and then I shall send you out from here, and when I have sent you out, all of you get yourselves out of here.
11.2: And say before the people that they shall ask, each man from his neighbor, and a woman from her neighbor, an article of silver and an article of gold.”
11.3: And LORD JEHOVAH gave favor to the people in the eyes of the Egyptians, also the man Moshe was highly honored in the land of Egypt, in the eyes of the Servants of Pharaoh and in the eyes of the people.
11.4: And Moshe said, “Thus says LORD JEHOVAH, ‘At midnight I go out within Egypt:
11.5: And all of the firstborn of the land of Egypt will die, from the firstborn of Pharaoh who sits on his throne even unto the firstborn of an handmaiden that is in the house of the millstone and all the firstborn of oxen.
11.6: And there shall be great wailing in the land of Egypt, the likes of which there has not been and there will not be.
11.7: And it will not harm one of the house of Israel, neither will a dog with his tongue, neither children of men, neither beast, so that you will know LORD JEHOVAH separated between Egyptians and one in the house of Israel.
11.8: And all of these your Servants shall come down to me and they will bow to me and they will say to me, ‘Go out, you and this people, all of your people, and then I shall go out’”, and Moshe went out from before Pharaoh in great anger.
11.9: And LORD JEHOVAH said to Moshe, “PHARAOH will not hear you because I shall magnify my signs in the land of Egypt.”
11.10: And Moshe and Aaron did these signs before Pharaoh and LORD JEHOVAH hardened the heart of Pharaoh and he did not send the children of Israel from his land.

12.1: And LORD JEHOVAH said to Moshe and to Aaron in the land of Egypt:
12.2: “This month shall be to you the beginning month before me; it shall be to you for all months of the year.
12.3: Say to all the assembly of the children of Israel in the tenth of this month, they shall take to them, each man, a lamb for the house and a lamb for the house of his father
12.4: And if the household is too small to bring out a lamb for it, he and his neighbor that is near to his house will take by the number of souls, each man according to his eating, you will count for a lamb.
12.5: A lamb that does not have a defect in it, it shall be yours, a male lamb a year old; you will take it from the lambs or from the goats:
12.6: And it will be kept with you until the fourteenth in this month and all the people of the assembly of the children of Israel will kill it at the setting of the sun.
12.7: And they will take from its blood and they will cast upon both door posts and upon the mantle and upon the houses where they will eat it among them.
12.8: And they will eat the flesh in this night when roasted in fire; they shall eat it and unleavened bread with bitter herbs.
12.9: You will not eat from it when living raw, also not by boiling in water, but roasted in fire, and its head, its legs and its insides.
12.10: And you shall not leave of it for the morning and anything that remains of it to the morning you shall burn in the fire.
12.11: And thus you will eat when your waists are tied and your shoes on your feet and your staves in your hands; eat it hastily because it is the Passover to LORD JEHOVAH.
12.12: And I shall pass through in the land of Egypt in this night and all the firstborn of the land of Egypt will die, from the sons of men and unto beast, and among all the worshiped creatures of the Egyptians I shall do judgment. I AM LORD JEHOVAH.
12.13: And this blood will be for a sign to you on the houses in which you are and I shall see the blood and I shall pass over you, and death will not be among you to destroy whenever I kill in the land of Egypt.
12.14: And this day will be for a remembrance to you, and make it a feast to LORD JEHOVAH, a feast to your generations; be doing it as a law for eternity.
12.15: Seven days you shall eat unleavened bread, and from the first day you shall remove the leaven from your houses, because everyone that will eat leavened bread from your houses, that soul will be lost from Israel, from the first day and unto the seventh day.
12.16: And the first day is called and holy, and the seventh day shall be called and holy to you, and no work shall be done in them, except whatever a son of man eats, only that will be done by you.
12.17: You shall keep the unleavened bread because in this day I have brought out your hosts from the land of Egypt and you shall keep this day for your generations, a law to eternity.
12.18: In the first month, in the fourteenth of the month in the evening you will eat unleavened bread and unto the twentyfirst day of the month in the evening.
12.19: For seven days leaven shall not be found in your houses, because everyone that will eat leaven, that soul will be lost from the assembly of Israel, of natives and of settlers of the land.
12.20: You shall eat no leaven; in every place of your dwelling you shall eat unleavened bread.
12.21: And Moshe called all the Elders of the children of Israel and he said to them, “Quickly take to yourselves lambs for your generations and kill the Passover.
12.22: And take a bunch of hyssop and dip it in the blood of a lamb and sprinkle on the lintels and upon both door posts from the blood that is in the vessel, and none of you shall go out from the door of his house until the morning.
12.23: And LORD JEHOVAH shall go through to strike the Egyptians and he shall see the blood that is upon the lintels and upon both door posts and LORD JEHOVAH shall pass over the door and shall not allow the Destroyer to enter your houses and destroy.
12.24: And you shall keep this statement and this Law for yourselves and for your children until eternity.
12.25: And whenever you have entered the land that LORD JEHOVAH shall give to you, as he said, you will keep this service.
12.26: And it will be when your children will say to you, ‘What is this service?’
12.27: You will say to them: ‘It is the sacrifice of the Passover of LORD JEHOVAH who passed over the houses of the children of Israel in Egypt when he struck the Egyptians, and he delivered our households.’ And the people knelt and worshipped LORD JEHOVAH.
12.28: And they went and the children of Israel did as LORD JEHOVAH commanded Moshe and Aaron, so they did.
12.29: And it was in the middle of the night and LORD JEHOVAH killed all of the firstborn of the land of Egypt, from the firstborn of Pharaoh who sat on his throne and unto the firstborn of the captive that is in the house of prisoners and all the firstborn of oxen.
12.30: And Pharaoh stood in that night and all his Servants and all Egyptians and there was great wailing in the land of Egypt, for there was not a house that did not have one dead in it.
12.31: And Pharaoh called Moshe and Ahron in that night and he said to them, “Arise, go out from within my people, even you and also the children of Israel, and go serve before LORD JEHOVAH just as you have said.
12.32: Also your flocks also your cattle take as you have said, and go and bless me also.”
12.33: And the Egyptians urged the people hastily that they would get them out from the land, because they said, “We all are dying!”
12.34: And the people took their bread dough when it had not fermented, their cold dough tied up in their towels and laid over their shoulders.
12.35: And the children of Israel did according to the word of Moshe and they requested from the Egyptians articles of silver and articles of gold and garments:
12.36: And LORD JEHOVAH gave favor to the people in the eyes of the Egyptians and they requested of them and they robbed the Egyptians.
12.37: And the children of Israel picked up from Raamsis to Sekoth, six hundred thousand men on foot, apart from the families.
12.38: Also many mixed companies went up with them and very many flocks and oxen and cattle.
12.39: And they baked the dough that the Egyptians had brought them, flat unleavened cake, because it had not fermented, because the Egyptians brought them out and they could not be rolled upland also they had made no provisions for them.
12.40: And their dwelling where the children of Israel had dwelt in Egypt was four hundred and thirty years.
12.41: And it was after four hundred and thirty years, on this day, all the armies of LORD JEHOVAH went out from the land of Egypt.
12.42: The night is kept to LORD JEHOVAH for their exodus from the land of Egypt; this night is kept to LORD JEHOVAH; it is for all the children of Israel for their generations.
12.43: And LORD JEHOVAH said to Moshe and Ahron: “This is the law of Passover: ‘No son of a foreigner will eat of it:
12.44: And every Servant of a man bought with money when you have circumcised him, then he will eat from it.
12.45: A settler and a hired man will not eat of it.
12.46: In one house it will be eaten and you shall not remove of its flesh outside of the house and the bones in it you shall not break.
12.47: All the assembly of Israel will perform it.
12.48: And when a settler will dwell with you and he will perform Passover to LORD JEHOVAH, whenever he circumcises any male, then he may come near to do it and he will be as a native of the land and no uncircumcised male will eat from it.
12.49: The law shall be one for the natives and for the settlers who dwell among you.”
12.50: And all the children of Israel did as LORD JEHOVAH commanded Moshe and Ahron; thus they did.
12.51: And it was in this day LORD JEHOVAH brought out the children of Israel from the land of Egypt, all their hosts.

13.1: And LORD JEHOVAH said to Moshe:
13.2: “Hallow to me every firstborn that opens every womb of the children of Israel, of men and of beast; they are mine.”
13.3: And Moshe said to the people: “Remember this day in which you came out from Egypt from the house of bondage, because by a mighty hand LORD JEHOVAH brought you out from here, and leaven will not be eaten.
13.4: On this day you are going out in the month of Habib.
13.5: And it will be when LORD JEHOVAH will bring you to the land of the Canaanites and of Khethites, and of Amorites, and of Khivites, and of Yebusites, and of Perezites, as he swore to your fathers to give to you the land that flows milk and honey, do this service in this month.
13.6: Seven days you will eat unleavened bread and in the seventh day it is a feast to LORD JEHOVAH.
13.7: Unleavened bread you will eat for seven days and leaven will not appear among you in your entire border.
13.8: And you shall tell your children in that day: “Because my God did this for me when I came out from Egypt.”
13.9: And it will be a sign to you on your hand and a remembrance between your eyes, so that the law of LORD JEHOVAH will be in your mouth, because by a mighty hand LORD JEHOVAH brought you out from Egypt.
13.10: And keep this commandment and this law for its time, from season to season.
13.11: And when LORD JEHOVAH will bring you to the land of the Canaanites, as He swore to you and to your fathers, and will give it to you,
13.12: You shall separate every firstborn opening the womb to LORD JEHOVAH, and every male opening the womb of oxen that you will have to LORD JEHOVAH.
13.13: And every firstborn male that opens the womb of cattle you shall redeem by a lamb, and if you do not redeem it, you will kill it, and you will redeem every firstborn of a son of man of your children.
13.14: And when your son may ask you tomorrow and will say to you, “What is this?”, say to him, “With a mighty hand LORD JEHOVAH brought us out from Egypt, from the house of bondage:
13.15: And when Pharaoh was hardened to our mission, LORD JEHOVAH killed all the firstborn ones that were in the land of Egypt, from the firstborn of a son of man and unto the firstborn ones of cattle; because of this I sacrifice to LORD JEHOVAH every male opening the womb and every firstborn of the sons I shall redeem.
13.16: And it will be a sign to you on your hand and a remembrance between your eyes, because by a mighty hand LORD JEHOVAH brought you out from Egypt.
13.17: And when Pharaoh sent the people God did not escort them in the way of the land of the Philistines because that was near, because God said, “Lest the people are afraid whenever they see war and they would return to Egypt:
13.18: And God led the people in the way of the wilderness of the Sea of Reeds, and they were armed; the house of Israel came up from the land of Egypt.
13.19: And Moshe took the bones of Yoseph with him because he made the house of Israel swear, and said, “God remembers to remember you. Bring up my bones from here with you.”
13.20: And they picked up from Sekoth and they camped in Atham which is at the end of the wilderness.
13.21: And LORD JEHOVAH went before them by day in a pillar of cloud to encamp them in the way, and by night in a pillar of fire to give light to them to go by day and by night:
13.22: He was not removing the pillar of cloud by day or the pillar of fire in the night from before the people.

14.1: And LORD JEHOVAH spoke with Moshe and said to him
14.2: “Say to them of the house of Israel, they shall turn and they shall camp on the mouth of Khritha, between Megdol and between the sea, before Baal Tsephon, you will camp by the sea opposite that.”
14.3: And Pharaoh said about the children of Israel: “They are strangers in the land; the wilderness has shut them in.”
14.4: And LORD JEHOVAH said to Moshe, “I shall harden the heart of Pharaoh and he will pursue after them, and I shall be glorified by Pharaoh and by all his army, and the Egyptians shall know that I AM LORD JEHOVAH”, and they did so.
14.5: And it was told to the King of Egypt that the people themselves were going and the heart of Pharaoh was turned and what they were doing concerning the people and they were saying, “What are we doing that we are sending Israel out from our subjection?”
14.6: And he harnessed his chariots and he took his people with him:
14.7: And he took six hundred chariots that were select and all the Egyptians and men over them all.
14.8: And LORD JEHOVAH hardened the heart of Pharaoh, the King of Egypt, and he pursued after the children of Israel and the children of Israel went out by a high hand.
14.9: And the Egyptians pursued after them and they overtook them when they camped by the sea; every horse of Pharaoh and his chariots and his horsemen and his army were camping on the mouth of Khritha opposite Baal Tsephon.
14.10: And Pharaoh came near and the house of Israel lifted up their eyes, and they saw the Egyptians as they came after them and they were very afraid and the children of Israel prayed before LORD JEHOVAH.
14.11: And they said to Moshe, “Because there are no tombs in Egypt have you led us that we should die in the wilderness? Why have you done so to us and have brought us out from Egypt?
14.12: Was this not the answer we were saying to you in Egypt: ‘Leave us that we may work for the Egyptians’, because it was better for us that we may work for the Egyptians than that we should die in this wilderness?”
14.13: And Moshe said to the people, “You shall not be afraid; wait and see the salvation of LORD JEHOVAH that He performs for you today, for as you see the Egyptians today, you will never see them again.
14.14: LORD JEHOVAH will fight for your persons when you will be calm”; and Moshe prayed before LORD JEHOVAH.
14.15: And LORD JEHOVAH said to Moshe, “Why do you pray before me? Say to the house of Israel, ‘We will pick up camp’:
14.16: And you lift your staff and stretch your hand over the sea and divide it, and the children of Israel shall enter within the sea on dry land.
14.17: And I, behold, I am hardening the heart of the Egyptians that they will enter after them and I shall be glorified by Pharaoh and by all his army, and by his chariots and by his horsemen.
14.18: And the Egyptians shall know that I AM LORD JEHOVAH when I am glorified by Pharaoh and by all his army and by his chariots and by his horsemen.
14.19: And the Angel of LORD JEHOVAH moved who went before the camp of Israel and he went on from behind them and moved the pillar of cloud from before them and stood behind them:
14.20: And it entered between the camp of the Egyptians and the encampment of Israel, and there was a cloud and darkness all night, and it shone all night to the children of Israel, and they did not approach them all night.
14.21: And Moshe lifted his hand over the sea and LORD JEHOVAH drove the sea back by a mighty hot Simoom wind all night, and he put the sea on land and the waters were divided.
14.22: And the children of Israel entered within the sea by land and the waters were to them as a wall from their right hand and from their left.
14.23: And the Egyptians pursued and all the horses of Pharaoh and his chariots and his horsemen went in after them within the sea.
14.24: And it was at the watch of dawn and LORD JEHOVAH appeared to the encampment of the Egyptians in a pillar of fire and of cloud and he stirred up tumult for the encampment of the Egyptians,
14.25: And he bound the wheels of their chariots and they drove them heavily and the Egyptians were saying, “Let us escape from before of the house of Israel, for LORD JEHOVAH fights war for them with Egypt.
14.26: And LORD JEHOVAH said to Moshe, “Arch your hand over the sea and the waters will return on the Egyptians, on their chariots and upon their horsemen.
14.27: And Moshe lifted his hand over the sea and the sea returned at the time of dawn to its place, and the Egyptians fled against it, and LORD JEHOVAH struck the Egyptians within the sea.
14.28: And the waters returned and covered the chariots and the horsemen and all the army of Pharaoh who went in after them into the sea, and none of them was left, not even one.
14.29: And the children of Israel walked in the sea as on dry land and the waters were to them like a wall on their right hand and on their left.
14.30: And LORD JEHOVAH saved Israel on that day from the hand of the Egyptians and Israel saw the Egyptians dead on the shore of the sea.
14.31: And Israel saw the great hand with which LORD JEHOVAH worked on the Egyptians and the people of LORD JEHOVAH were in awe and they believed in LORD JEHOVAH and in Moshe his Servant.

15.1: Then Moshe and the children of Israel sang this song to LORD JEHOVAH and they said: “We will praise glorious LORD JEHOVAH Who exulted over the horses, and their riders he cast into the sea.
15.2: The Mighty One and the Glorious YAH, LORD JEHOVAH, and he is to us the Savior; this is my God, I shall glorify him, the God of my fathers, I shall exalt him.
15.3: LORD JEHOVAH, the Mighty Man and the Warrior; LORD JEHOVAH is his name.
15.4: The chariots of Pharaoh and his army he cast into the sea and he drowned the chosen of his mighty men in The Sea of Reeds.
15.5: The depths covered them; they went down to the depth and they sank like a stone.
15.6: Your right hand, LORD JEHOVAH, is glorious in power; your right hand, LORD JEHOVAH, has broken your enemies.
15.7: And in the abundance of your strength you have pulled down those hating you; you have sent your wrath and it consumed them like trash.
15.8: By the Breath of your nostrils the waters stood up in a heap; they stood up as if they were flowing in water skins; the depths assembled in the heart of the sea.
15.9: The enemy said, “I shall pursue and I shall overtake; I shall divide the loot; my soul will devour them; I shall draw my sword and my hand will destroy them.”
15.10: Your wind blew and the sea covered them; they sank like lead in the mighty waters.
15.11: Who is like you LORD JEHOVAH? Who is like you, glorious in his holiness, fearsome and glorious and doing wonders?
15.12: You have lifted your right hand and the Earth swallowed them.
15.13: You led in your kindness this people which you have saved; you have led them by your power to the fold of your holiness.
15.14: The nations heard and they shook, and fear has seized the dwellers of Philistia.
15.15: Then the Princes of Adum were afraid, and trembling seized the men of Moab; all the inhabitants of Canaan broke down.
15.16: Fear and shaking will fall upon them by the greatness of your arm; they will sink like a stone until your people will pass through, LORD JEHOVAH, until this people which you have saved will pass through.
15.17: You will bring them forth and you will plant them in the mountain of your inheritance, fashioned for your dwelling. You have made, LORD JEHOVAH, your holy place; LORD JEHOVAH, you have fashioned it with your hands.
15.18: LORD JEHOVAH will reign to the eternity of eternities.
15.19: Because the horses of Pharaoh and his chariots and his horsemen went into the sea and LORD JEHOVAH returned the waters of the sea upon them and the children of Israel walked on dry land within the sea.
15.20: And Maryam the Prophetess, the sister of Ahron, took tambourines in her hand and all the women went out after her with tambourines and with timbrels.
15.21: And Maryam was answering them: “Sing to glorious LORD JEHOVAH Who exulted over the horses, and their riders he cast into the sea.”
15.22: And Moshe moved them of the house of Israel from The Sea of Reeds and they went out to the wilderness of Shood, and they came three days’ journey in the wilderness and they did not find water.
15.23: And they came to Murath and they did not find drinking waters from Murath because they were bitter; because of this, he called the name of that country Murath.
15.24: And the people were enraged against Moshe and they were saying to him, “What will we drink?”
15.25: And Moshe prayed before LORD JEHOVAH, and LORD JEHOVAH showed him wood and he cast it into the water and the waters became sweet there. He taught him the Law and judgment and there he tested him,
15.26: And he said to him, “If you will listen to hear the voice of LORD JEHOVAH your God and you will do what is good before Him, and you will obey his commandments and you will keep all of his statutes, I shall bring none of the plagues that I brought on the Egyptians upon you, because I AM LORD JEHOVAH your healer.”
15.27: And they came to Alim and there were twelve fountains of waters there and seventy palm trees, and they camped there at the waters.

16.1: And they picked up from Alim and all the assembly of the children of Israel came to the wilderness of Sin that is between Alim and Sinai in the fifteenth of the second month from the time that the children of Israel had gone from Egypt.
16.2: And all of the assembly of the children of Israel complained against Moshe and against Ahron in the wilderness:
16.3: And the children of Israel said to them: “We were wishing that we had died by the hand of LORD JEHOVAH in the land of Egypt when we were sitting by the pots of flesh and we were eating bread and were full, for you brought us to this wilderness to destroy the whole assembly of the children of Israel with hunger.”
16.4: And LORD JEHOVAH said to Moshe, “Behold, I rain for you bread from Heaven, and the people shall come out and they will gather food of the day in the daytime, because I shall test them if they are walking in my laws or not.
16.5: And it will be in the sixth day they shall prepare what they bring and each one will be double over anything that they gather on every day.”
16.6: And Moshe and Ahron said to all the children of Israel, “In the evening you will know that LORD JEHOVAH brought you out from Egypt:
16.7: And at dawn you will see the glory of LORD JEHOVAH, because your complaining was heard before LORD JEHOVAH, and we, who are we, that you were complaining against us?”
16.8: And Moshe said to them, “Whenever LORD JEHOVAH gives you flesh in the evening to eat and bread at dawn to be satisfied, because LORD JEHOVAH heard your complaining that you were complaining against him (and we, who are we?), it was not against us that you complained but against LORD JEHOVAH.”
16.9: And Moshe said to Ahron, “Say to all the assembly of the children of Israel, ‘Come before LORD JEHOVAH, because he has heard your complaining.’
16.10: And it was that when Ahron spoke to all the assembly of the children of Israel, they were turned to the wilderness, and behold, the glory of LORD JEHOVAH appeared in a cloud.
16.11: And LORD JEHOVAH said to Moshe,
16.12: “I have heard the grumbling of the children of Israel; say to them, “At the setting the sun you are eating meat, and at dawn you will be filled with bread, and you will know that I AM LORD JEHOVAH your God.”
16.13: And it was in the evening and the quail came up and covered the encampment, and at dawn there was a being, a mist of dew around the camp.
16.14: And the mist of dew went up, and behold, on the face of the wilderness, fine and skinned off and a layer like frost on the ground.
16.15: And the children of Israel saw, and they said, each man to his brother, “What is this? What is it?”, because they did not know what it was. Moshe said to them, “This is the bread that LORD JEHOVAH gives you to eat.”
16.16: And this statement LORD JEHOVAH was commanding: a man is to gather from it a sufficiency for his consumption, a measure to a head, the number of your souls; you will take, each man, for one who is in his tent.
16.17: And in this way the children of Israel did, and some gathered much, and some little.
16.18: And they measured it in a measure, and those who had much had nothing left over, and those who had little did not lack; they gathered each man enough for his consumption.
16.19: Moshe said to them, “A man shall not leave some of it for the morning.”
16.20: And they did not listen to Moshe and they left some of it, each man, for the morning, and it caused crawling worms and it stank, and Moshe was angry with them.
16.21: And they were gathering it at dawn; at dawn each man had enough for his consumption, and whenever the sun became hot, it was melting.
16.22: And it was in the sixth day they collected bread by two measures for each person, and all the Elders of the assembly came and showed Moshe.
16.23: Moshe said to them, “This is what LORD JEHOVAH said: The Sabbath rest is holiness to LORD JEHOVAH. Tomorrow anything that you bake, bake, and anything that you boil, boil, and anything that is left keep cold for yourselves for the morning.
16.24: And they left some of it for the morning, as Moshe commanded them, and it did not stink and no creeping thing was in it.
16.25: Moshe said to them, “Eat it today, because today is the Sabbath to LORD JEHOVAH; today you will not find it in the field.
16.26: Six days you will be gathering it and the seventh day is the Sabbath; there is none in it.
16.27: And it was on the seventh day, some people went out to collect and they did not find any.
16.28: And LORD JEHOVAH said to Moshe, “How long will you not keep my commands and my law?
16.29: See that LORD JEHOVAH gave to you the Sabbath, because of this LORD JEHOVAH gave bread of two days to you on the sixth day; each man shall return into his place and a man will not come forth from the door of his house on the seventh day.
16.30: And the people were rested on the seventh day.
16.31: And the children of Israel called its name manna, and it was like the seed of white coriander, and its taste like honeycomb of honey.
16.32: And Moshe said, “This is the message that LORD JEHOVAH commanded: ‘Fill a measure of it; it will be preserved for your generations so that they will see the bread that I fed you in the wilderness when I brought you out from Egypt.’”
16.33: And Moshe said to Ahron, “Take one pot and cast a full measure of manna into it and set it before LORD JEHOVAH to be preserved for your generations.
16.34: Just as LORD JEHOVAH has taught me”, and Ahron placed it for a testimony to be preserved.
16.35: And the children of Israel ate manna forty years until they arrived at an inhabited land. They ate manna until they arrived at the border of the land of Canaan.
16.36: And a measure was one tenth of a bushel.

17.1: And all the assembly of the children of Israel picked up from the wilderness of Sin for their journey upon the word of the mouth of LORD JEHOVAH, and they camped in Raphidin, and there was no water that the people would drink.
17.2: And the people disputed with Moshe and they said to him, “Give us water we will drink”; Moshe said to them, “Why are you arguing with me and why are you tempting LORD JEHOVAH?”
17.3: And there the people were thirsty for water and the people complained against Moshe and they said to him, “Why have you brought us out from Egypt to kill us, us and our children and our animals with thirst?”
17.4: And Moshe prayed before LORD JEHOVAH and he said, “What shall I do for this people, for in a little bit they will stone me?”
17.5: And LORD JEHOVAH said to Moshe: “Pass before the people and take with you some Elders of Israel, and take your staff in your hand with which you struck the river, and go.
17.6: And behold, I am standing there before you on the flint in Khoreeb, and strike the flint and water shall come out from it and the people will drink.” And Moshe did in this way before the eyes of the Elders of the children of Israel.
17.7: And he called the name of that country Nasa and Meriba, because the children of Israel contended and because they tested LORD JEHOVAH and they said, “If LORD JEHOVAH is with us or not?”
17.8: And Amaleq came to make war with Israel in Raphidin.
17.9: And Moshe said to Yeshua, “Choose for you men and come out; we shall make war with Amaleq tomorrow, and behold, I am standing on the top of the hill and the staff of God is in my hand.
17.10: And Yeshua did according to what Moshe said to him and he went on to make war with Amaleq, and Moshe and Ahron and Khur came up to the top the hill.
17.11: And when Moshe was raising his hands, Israel was prevailing, and when he was resting his hands, Amaleq was prevailing.
17.12: And the hands of Moshe were weary and they took a stone and they placed it under him and he sat down upon it and Ahron and Khur were upholding his hands, one from here and one from there, and his hands were in steadfastness until the sun had set.
17.13: And Yeshua shattered Amaleq and his people by the mouth of the sword.
17.14: And LORD JEHOVAH said to Moshe, “Write this memorial in a book and put it before Yeshua, son of Nun, because certainly I blot out the memory of Amaleq from under Heaven.
17.15: And Moshe built an altar and he called its name Marya Nassi LORD JEHOVAH Tested.
17.16: And he said, “Behold, the hand on the throne of war with LORD JEHOVAH in Amaleq from the generation of generations.”

18.1: And Yethrown the Priest of Midian, Father in Law of Moshe, heard everything that God did for Moshe and for Israel his people, because LORD JEHOVAH brought forth the children of Israel from Egypt;
18.2: And Yethrown, Father in Law of Moshe, took Tsephora his daughter, the wife of Moshe, after he released her,
18.3: And her two children, one of whose names was Gershon, because he said, “I was a stranger in a strange land”:
18.4: And the name of the other, Eliazer, because “The God of my fathers was my help and he delivered me from the sword of Pharaoh”:
18.5: And Yethrown, Father in Law of Moshe, and his children and his wife came to Moshe, to the wilderness, who was camping there at the mountain of God:
18.6: And it was said to Moshe, “Behold, your Father in Law Yethrown has come to you, and your wife and both your sons with him.
18.7: And Moshe went out to meet his Father in Law, and he bowed to him and he kissed him and they invoked, each man, the peace of his fellow, and they entered the tent.
18.8: And Moshe related to his Father in Law everything that LORD JEHOVAH did to Pharaoh and to the Egyptians concerning the possessions of the children of Israel and all the labor that they labored on the way, and LORD JEHOVAH delivered them.
18.9: And Yethrown rejoiced over all the good that LORD JEHOVAH did for Israel and he delivered them from the hand of the Egyptians and from the hand of Pharaoh.
18.10: And Yethrown said, “Blessed is LORD JEHOVAH who has delivered you from the hand of the Egyptians and from the hand of Pharaoh, who has saved his people from under the hand of the Egyptians.
18.11: Now I know that LORD JEHOVAH is greater than all gods, because of the scheme that they had plotted against them.
18.12: And Yethrown, the Father in Law of Moshe, offered burning peace offerings and sacrifices to LORD JEHOVAH, and Ahron and all Elders of the children of Israel came to eat bread with the Father in Law of Moshe before God.
18.13: And it was the next day and Moshe sat down to judge the people, and the people were standing over from Moshe from dawn and unto evening.
18.14: And the Father in Law of Moshe saw everything that he did for the people and he said to him, “What is this matter that you do for the people? Why do you sit alone and all the people stand over from you from dawn and unto evening?”
18.15: And Moshe said to his Father in Law, “The people come to me to ask the word from God:
18.16: And when they have a matter they come to me and I judge between a man with his neighbor and I show to them the commandments of God and his laws.”
18.17: And his Father in Law said to Moshe, you are not doing well.
18.18: Being dishonored you are also shamed, so is also all this people that are with you, because the matter is too heavy for you and you cannot do it alone.
18.19: Now hear my voice and I shall counsel you and God will be with you. You are a Teacher to the people from God and you have been bringing their concerns before God:
18.20: And you should warn them so that they keep the commandments and the Law, and show them the way to go in it and the works to do.
18.21: And you shall see from all the people men of power who are in awe of God, faithful men and they hate a bribe and deceit and set over them Chiefs of thousands and Chiefs of hundreds and Chiefs of fifties and Chiefs of tens:
18.22: And they shall be judges to the people in every time and when a great matter will come to you, those shall judge all small matters and it will unburden you and they will bear it with you.
18.23: And if you do this thing God commands you, also you can stand, also all these people, each one, shall depart to his house in peace.
18.24: And Moshe heard the voice of his Father in Law and he did everything that he said to him.
18.25: And Moshe chose men of power from all Israel and he set them up as Chiefs over the people, Chiefs of thousands and Chiefs of hundreds and Chiefs of fifties and Chiefs of tens.
18.26: And they were judging the people at all times, and they were bringing difficult matters to Moshe, and they were judging little matters.
18.27: And Moshe sent his Father in Law and he went on to his land.

19.1: In the third month after the exodus of the children of Israel from Egypt, on this day they came to the wilderness of Sin.
19.2: And they moved camp from Raphidin and they came to the wilderness of Sinai and they camped in the wilderness, and Israel camped there against the mountain.
19.3: And Moshe went up to God and God called to him from the mountain and he said: “Thus say to those of the house of Yaquuv and tell the children of Israel;
19.4: ‘You have seen what I have done to the Egyptians and I have carried you as upon wings of eagles and I have brought you to me.
19.5: And now if you will hear to listen to my voice and you will keep my covenant, you will be more beloved to me than all the nations of the Earth, because the Earth is mine
19.6: And you will be to me a kingdom and Priests and a holy people’; say these words to the house of Israel.”
19.7: And Moshe came and he called the Elders of the people and told all these statements before them that LORD JEHOVAH had commanded him.
19.8: And all the people answered as one and they said, “Everything that LORD JEHOVAH said we will do”, and Moshe returned the answer of the people to LORD JEHOVAH.
19.9: And LORD JEHOVAH said to Moshe, “Behold, I came to you in thick darkness of cloud so that the people will hear when I speak with you, also they shall believe you for eternity”, and Moshe showed the answer of the people before LORD JEHOVAH.
19.10: And LORD JEHOVAH said to Moshe, “Go to the people and hallow them today and tomorrow, and they will wash their clothes,
19.11: And they shall be ready for the third day, because in the third day LORD JEHOVAH shall go down before the eyes of all the people to the mountain of Sinai:
19.12: And raise a testimony among the people and say to them, ‘Beware you will not come up to the mountain and you shall not touch its borders and everyone who touches the mountain will be killed.
19.13: A hand shall not come near it lest, being stoned, one will be stoned, and shot, he will be shot; if it is a beast or if a son of man, he shall not live, and when the trumpet has been silent, you are allowed to go up the mountain.’”
19.14: And Moshe came down from the mountain to the people and hallowed the people and they whitened their garments.
19.15: And he said to the people, “Be ready the third day; you shall not touch a woman.”
19.16: And it was in the third day, when it was dawn, there were voices and lightnings and a mighty cloud was on the mountain and a sound of a trumpet was very powerful and all the people that were in the camp shook.
19.17: And Moshe brought out the people to the meeting of God from the camp and they stood at the base of the mountain.
19.18: And the mountain of Sinai was entirely smoking because LORD JEHOVAH descended upon it in fire and its smoke came up as the smoke of a furnace and the whole mountain shook greatly.
19.19: And the sound of the trumpet was going on and had grown very strong, and Moshe was speaking and God answered him in a voice.
19.20: And LORD JEHOVAH came down to the mountain of Sinai to the top of the mountain, and LORD JEHOVAH called Moshe to the top of the mountain and Moshe came up.
19.21: And LORD JEHOVAH said to Moshe, “Go down; testify among the people that they do not go too far before LORD JEHOVAH to see, or many of them will fall.
19.22: Also the Priests who come near to LORD JEHOVAH shall be hallowed, lest LORD JEHOVAH will overpower them."
19.23: And Moshe said to LORD JEHOVAH, “The people cannot ascend the mountain of Sinai because you testified with us and you said to me, “Set boundaries to the mountain and hallow it.”
19.24: And LORD JEHOVAH said to him, “Go, go down and come up, you and Ahron your brother with you, and do not let the Priests and people go far to go up before LORD JEHOVAH, lest he kill some of them.”
19.25: And Moshe came down to the people and spoke to them.

20.1: And God said all these words,
20.2: “I AM LORD JEHOVAH your God who brought you out from the land of Egypt from the house of bondage.
20.3: You shall not have other gods outside of me.
20.4: You shall not make for you any image or any form that is in Heaven from above or what is in the earth from beneath or what is in the water beneath the Earth:
20.5: You shall not bow to them and you shall not serve them because I AM LORD JEHOVAH your God, a jealous God; he pays the love debts of fathers for the children unto three and unto four generations for those hating me;
20.6: And I produce grace to thousands of generations of My friends and those keeping my commands.
20.7: You shall not swear in the Name of LORD JEHOVAH your God with a lie because LORD JEHOVAH does not declare him innocent who swears in his Name with a lie.
20.8: Remember the day of the Sabbath for its holiness.
20.9: Six days you shall serve and you shall do all your work:
20.10: And the seventh day is the Sabbath to LORD JEHOVAH your God; you shall not do any work, you or your son or your daughter or your Servant or your Maidservant or your beast or your settler who is in your town:
20.11: Because for six days LORD JEHOVAH made Heaven and Earth and the seas and everything that is in them, and he was refreshed in the seventh day; because of this, LORD JEHOVAH blessed the seventh day and hallowed it.
20.12: Honor your father and your mother that your days will increase in the land that LORD JEHOVAH your God gives to you.
20.16: You shall not testify a false testimony against your neighbor.
20.17: You shall not lust for the house of your neighbor; you shall not lust for the wife of your neighbor or his Servant or his Maid Servant or his ox or his donkey or anything that is your neighbor’s.
20.18: And all the people saw the voices and lamps lightnings and the sound of the trumpet and the mountain smoking, and the people saw and they were afraid and they stood at a distance.
20.19: And they said to Moshe, “You speak with us and we will hear and do not let God speak with us, lest we die.”
20.20: And Moshe said to the people, “You shall not be afraid, because God has come to test you and so that his awe may be before your faces and that you will not sin.”
20.21: And the people stood at a distance and Moshe came to the thick darkness of the place of God.
20.22: And LORD JEHOVAH said to Moshe: “In this way speak to those of the house of Israel: “You have seen that I have spoken with you from Heaven.
20.23: You shall not make for yourselves gods of gold with me, neither gods of silver shall you make for yourselves.
20.24: An altar of earth you shall make to me and you will offer upon it your burnt offerings and your offerings and your sheep and your oxen; in every place that you will commemorate My Name I shall come to you and I shall bless you.
20.25: And if you make to me an altar of stone, you shall not build it with cut stone because you have lifted up iron upon it and you have polluted it.
20.26: And you shall not go up by stairs to my altar so that your nakedness will not be revealed upon it.

21.1: And these are the judgments that you shall set before them.
21.2: When you will buy a Hebrew Servant, six years he will serve you and in the seventh he will go forth as a son of freedom from your presence.
21.3: And if he alone will come in, he alone will go forth, and if he is a husband of a wife, his wife will go out with him.
21.4: And if his Master will give him a woman and she shall bear to him sons and daughters, the wife and her children will be his Master’s and he will go forth alone.
21.5: And if a Servant will say, “I Love my Master and my wife and my children; I am not going out a son of freedom”:
21.6: His Master shall bring him to the Judges and they shall bring him to the door or to the door post and his Master shall bore his ear with an awl and he will be his, doing service for life.
21.7: And when a man will sell his daughter as a Maidservant, she will not go out as Men Servants will leave.
21.8: If she is hated in the eyes of her Master so that he will not take her, let him redeem her for a foreign people; it is not legal for him to sell her, because he was false to her.
21.9: And if he will take her for his son, he shall do for her according to the Law of what is done to a daughter.
21.10: And if he will take to himself another wife; her provisions and her clothing and her bed he shall not take.
21.11: And if he will not do these three things to her, she will go out freely without expense.
21.12: He who strikes a man and the man dies, shall certainly be killed.
21.13: And he who did not lie in ambush for him and God handed him over into his hand, make for you a place that he may flee there.
21.14: And if a man will presume against his neighbor and will kill him by treachery, take him from the presence of my altar to kill him.
21.15: He who will strike his father or his mother shall certainly be killed.
21.16: He who will steal a person and will sell him and be found with him surely shall be killed.
21.17: He who will revile his father or his mother surely shall be killed.
21.18: And when two men will fight and a man will strike his neighbor with a stone or by force and he will not die and he will fall ill:
21.19: If he shall rise and he will walk in the street on his staff, he who hit him will be innocent, only he will give him his loss of work and the hire of a Physician.
21.20: And when a man will strike his Servant or his maid with a rod and one dies under his hand, he shall certainly be judged.
21.21: However, if one shall live one day or two days, he will not be judged because that is his money.
21.22: And when two men will fight and they strike a woman who is pregnant and her infant shall come out and there will be no misfortune, certainly he shall be fined according to what the husband of the woman lays upon him, and he will give as the Judges decide.
21.23: And if there is misfortune, he will give a life in exchange for a life,
21.24: An eye in exchange for an eye, a tooth in exchange for a tooth, a hand in exchange of a hand, a foot in exchange for a foot.
21.25: Branding in exchange for branding, wound in exchange for wound, a blow in exchange for a blow.
21.26: And when a man will strike the eye of his Servant or the eye of his Maidservant and will injure it, he will send him/her away a person of freedom for the sake of his/her eye.
21.27: And if he will knock out a tooth of his Servant or a tooth of his Maidservant, he will send that person away as a person of freedom for the sake of his tooth.
21.28: And when an ox will gore a man or a woman and someone will die, the ox surely will be stoned and its flesh shall not be eaten and the owner of the ox shall be declared innocent.
21.29: And if the ox was a gorer from yesterday or from before it and they testified before its owner and he did not keep it and it will kill a man or a woman, the ox will be stoned, also its owner will be killed.
21.30: And if they shall impose money upon him, he will give the redemption of his life as much as they ask him.
21.31: And if an ox will gore a son or a daughter, it will be done to it according to this judgment.
21.32: And if an ox will gore a Servant or a Maidservant, he shall give thirty shekels of silver to his/her Master and the ox shall be stoned.
21.33: And when a man will open a pit or a man will dig a well and will not cover them and an ox or a donkey will fall there;
21.34: The owner of the pit will pay money to its owner and the dead animal shall be his.
21.35: And when the ox of a man will gore the ox of another man, his neighbor, and it will die, they will sell the living ox and shall divide its money, also they shall divide that which is dead.
21.36: And if it will be known that an ox was a gorer from yesterday or from the day before yesterday, and its owner did not keep it in, he will give an ox in exchange for the ox and the dead ox shall be his.

22.1: And when a man will steal an ox or a ewe and he will kill them or he will sell them, he will give five oxen in exchange for an ox and four ewes he will give in exchange for a ewe.
22.2: And if a thief will be found breaking in and he is wounded and dies, there is no vengeance for him.
22.3: And if the sun has risen upon him there is vengeance for him, and paying he will pay, and if he has nothing, he shall be sold for his theft.
22.4: And if when he is caught, the theft of an ox or a donkey and unto a ewe shall be found in his hands still alive, he shall restore each by two.
22.5: And when a man will consume a field or a vineyard and will loose his cattle and will consume in another field, he shall pay from the good of his field and from the good of his vineyard.
22.6: And when fire goes forth and it will find the thorns and will devour the shocks or the standing grain or the field, he who kindled the fire shall certainly restore.
22.7: And when a man will give his neighbor money or a garment to keep and it is stolen from the house of the man, if the thief be found he will restore each thing double.
22.8: And if the thief will not be found, let the owner of the house approach to the Judge, if he did not reach his hand into the property of his neighbor
22.9: Concerning every matter of sin about an ox or about a donkey or about a sheep or about clothing or about every loss of which one says, “This is it” before the Judges, the words of both shall enter and he whom the Judges convict will restore each thing double to his neighbor.
22.10: And when a man will give his neighbor a donkey or an ox or a sheep or any animal to keep and it will die or will be injured or will be stolen and there is not a man who sees
22.11: An oath of LORD JEHOVAH will be between both: “Surely he did not stretch his hand into the property of his neighbor” and their owner would take the oaths and will not restore
22.12: And if it will be certainly stolen from him, he will restore to its owner.
22.13: And if it will be certainly injured and he shall bring it for a witness that it is injured, he will not restore it.
22.14: And when a man will ask an animal from his neighbor and it will be injured or it would die and its owner was not with it, he shall surely restore it.
22.15: And if its owner was with it, he shall not restore it, and if it was hired he will eat its hire.
22.16: And when a man will seduce a virgin that was not engaged and he shall have sexual intercourse with her, he shall surely take her to him as a wife.
22.17: And if her father does not choose to give her to him, he shall weigh out money as a marriage dowry of the virgin.
22.18: You shall not let a sorcerer live.
22.19: And everyone whoever will have sexual intercourse with an animal shall surely be killed.
22.20: He who will sacrifice to objects of worship, if not to LORD JEHOVAH alone, shall be destroyed.
22.21: And do not harm, neither distress settlers, because you were settlers in the land of Egypt.
22.22: And do not harm any widow or orphan.
22.23: And if you trouble them and they pray before me, I shall certainly hear their prayers;
22.24: And my anger will be kindled and I shall kill you with sword and your wives shall be widowed and your children shall be orphaned.
22.25: And if you lend money to my people, the poor of your people, you will not be as a creditor to him and do not take interest from him.
22.26: And if you take the garment of your neighbor as a pledge, at the setting the sun, give it to him:
22.27: Because that is his garment alone and it is his covering for his body. With what will he sleep? And if he will pray before me I shall hear him, because I am compassionate.
22.28: Do not vilify the Judge and do not curse the Ruler of your people.
22.29: You shall not delay the beginning of the harvests of your threshing floor or the first of your wine press; the firstborn of your sons you shall give to me.
22.30: And thus you shall do to your oxen and to your sheep: seven days he shall be with his mother, and on the eighth day you give him to me.
22.31: And you shall be holy people to me and the flesh that is torn apart by living animals you shall not eat; you shall cast it to the dogs.

23.1: You shall not confirm a false report; you shall not stretch your hand with the guilty to be a lying witness for him.
23.2: You shall not go after many to do evil and do not answer against judgment to turn away after many who do turn away:
23.3: And you shall not favor the poor in his judgment.
23.4: And when you will come upon the ox of your enemy or upon his donkey when going astray, be sure to return them to him.
23.5: And when you shall see the donkey of your enemy that is lying under his burden and you do not want to lift it up, surely lift it up.
23.6: You shall not decline the justice of the poor in his judgment.
23.7: And keep far away from a lying word, and you shall not kill the innocent ones and the righteous ones, because I do not justify the guilty.
23.8: Do not take a bribe because a bribe puts out the eyes of the wise in judgment and subverts the words of the innocent.
23.9: And do not distress foreigners, for you know the soul of foreigners, because you were strangers in the land of Egypt.
23.10: Six years you shall sow your land and you shall gather in its harvests:
23.11: And in the seventh you shall plough it and you shall leave it and the poor of your people shall eat and the animals of the wilderness will devour their remainder and thus you shall do to your vineyards and to your olive yards.
23.12: In six days you shall do your work and in the seventh day you shall rest, so that your ox and your donkey will rest, and the son of your maid Servant will be refreshed, and the stranger that is in your towns.
23.13: And pay attention to everything that I said to you and you shall not call to mind the name of other objects of worship and it shall not come up on your heart.
23.14: Make to me a feast three times in a year.
23.15: You shall keep the feast of unleavened bread seven days; you shall eat unleavened bread as I ordered you in the month of Habiba, because in the month of Habiba you went out from Egypt, and you shall not appear before me empty.
23.16: And the feast of beginning harvest of your crops that you will sow in a field, and the feast of ingathering in the outgoing of the year when you have gathered your increase from the field.
23.17: Three times in a year all your commemorations shall appear before LORD JEHOVAH your God.
23.18: You shall not offer blood of sacrifice with leaven and the fat of feasts will not remain until the morning.
23.19: The beginning of the harvests of your land you shall bring to the house of LORD JEHOVAH your God; you shall not boil a goat in the milk of its mother.
23.20: Behold, I am sending a Messenger before you, for he will keep you on the path and he will bring you to the land that I have prepared.
23.21: Beware of him and listen to his voice; do not contend against him, lest he will not forgive your sins, because my Name is upon him.
23.22: And if you will listen to hear his voice and you will do everything that he says to you, I shall hate those hating you and I shall distress your enemies.
23.23: Because My Messenger will go before you and he will bring you against the Amorites, and the Hittites, and the Perizzites, and the Canaanites, and the Khivites and the Yebusites, and I shall destroy them.
23.24: You shall not worship their gods and you shall not serve them, neither shall you do according to their works, but certainly cast them down and certainly break their monuments.
23.25: And you shall serve LORD JEHOVAH your God, and he shall bless your bread and your water, and plagues shall pass by from your houses.
23.26: And there will be no one sterile and no one barren in your land, and I shall fulfill the number of your days.
23.27: And I shall send my awe before you and I shall destroy all the nations where you go against them and I shall cause your enemies to turn their back before you.
23.28: And I shall send bees before you and I shall destroy the Canaanites and the Khethites from before you.
23.29: I shall not destroy them from before you in one year, that the land will not be a desolation, and wild animals multiply upon you.
23.30: Little by little I shall destroy them from before you, until you will prevail and you will inherit the land.
23.31: And I shall make your borders from the Sea of Reeds and unto the Sea of the Philistines, and from the wilderness and unto the river, because I deliver the dwellers of the land into your hands and you will destroy them.
23.32: You shall not cause a covenant to stand with them and with their idols.
23.33: And they shall not dwell in your land, lest they cause you to sin before me, and you shall not serve their gods, that they will not be a stumbling block to you.

24.1: And to Moshe he said, “Come up to LORD JEHOVAH, you and Ahron and Nadab and Abihu and seventy men of the Elders of Israel, and you shall worship from a distance.
24.2: And Moshe alone will come near before LORD JEHOVAH, and they will not approach, and the people will not come up with him.
24.3: And Moshe came and he related to the people all of the statements of LORD JEHOVAH and all the judgments, and all the people cried out in one voice, and they said, “Everything that LORD JEHOVAH says, we shall do!”
24.4: And Moshe wrote all of the statements of LORD JEHOVAH, and he arose at dawn and built an altar on the outskirts of the mountain and twelve pillars for the twelve tribes of Israel.
24.5: And he sent the youths of the children of Israel and they offered up burning peace offerings and they sacrificed peace sacrifices, bullocks to LORD JEHOVAH.
24.6: And Moshe took half of the blood and cast it into basins and half of the blood he poured on the altar.
24.7: And he took the Book of the Covenant and he read before the people and they said, “Everything that LORD JEHOVAH said, we will hear and we will do”
24.8: And Moshe took the blood and he sprinkled it on the people and said, “This is the blood of the Covenant that LORD JEHOVAH covenanted with you by all of these words.”
24.9: And Moshe and Ahron and Nadab and Abihu and seventy of the Elders of Israel came up:
24.10: And they saw the God of Israel, and under his feet there was as the work of tile of sapphire, and like the color of the sky in purity.
24.11: And upon the Elders of the children of Israel he did not stretch his hand, and they saw God, and they ate and they drank.
24.12: And LORD JEHOVAH said to Moshe, “Come up to me to the mountain and be there and I shall give to you tablets of stone and the laws and the commandments that I have written to teach them.”
24.13: And Moshe stood and Hoshea his Minister, and Moshe came up to the mountain of God.
24.14: And to the Elders he said, “Wait for us here until we return to you; and behold, Ahron and Khur are with you; he that has a matter, he will come before them.”
24.15: And Moshe came up to the mountain and a cloud covered it.
24.16: And the glory of LORD JEHOVAH dwelt on the mountain of Sinai and a cloud covered it six days, and LORD JEHOVAH called Moshe on the seventh day from within the cloud.
24.17: And he saw the glory of LORD JEHOVAH as fire that burned on the top of the mountain before the eyes of the entire house of Israel.
24.18: And Moshe entered within the cloud and he came up to the mountain and Moshe was in the mountain forty days and forty nights.

25.1: And LORD JEHOVAH spoke with Moshe and said to him:
25.2: “Speak to them of the house of Israel and they will separate to me an offering from every man; what is considered in his heart you shall receive as an offering.
25.3: And this is the offering that you shall receive of them: gold and silver and brass,
25.4: And dark blue fringes, and purple, and scarlet, and fine white linen, and hair of goats,
25.5: And skin of rams that is dyed red, and skin of vermilion or sky blue, and wood of box tree,
25.6: And oil to give light, and fragrances to anoint for an anointing, and for incense of sweet spices,
25.7: And stones of Beryl, and precious stones for the ephod and for the breastplate.
25.8: And they will make to me a sanctuary and I shall dwell among them.
25.9: Everything that I show to you, the likeness of the Tabernacle and of all its implements, in this way they shall do.
25.10: And they shall make an ark of the wood of the box tree, two cubits and a half its length, and a cubit and a half its width, and a cubit and a half its height.
25.11: And overlay it with pure gold on the outside, and from within you shall overlay it, and you shall make for it a crown of gold encircling.
25.12: And you shall forge for it four rings of gold and you shall put on the four corners, two rings on one side and two rings on its other side.
25.13: And you shall make poles of the wood of the box tree and you shall overlay them in gold.
25.14: And you shall put the poles in the rings on the side of the ark by which the ark will be carried.
25.15: The poles shall be in the rings of the ark and they shall not be taken away from them.
25.16: And you will put in the ark the testimony that I shall give to you.
25.17: And make the Mercy Seat of pure gold, two cubits and a half its length and a cubit and a half its width.
25.18: And make two Cherubim of gold; make them of smelting from the two sides of the Mercy Seat.
25.19: And make one Cherub at its side from here and another Cherub at the other side of the Mercy Seat; you shall make two Cherubim on its two sides.
25.20: And the Cherubim shall be extending their wings over and covering over the Mercy Seat with their wings, and their faces one against another; the faces of the Cherubim will be over the Mercy Seat.
25.21: And you will put the Mercy Seat on the ark from above and you will put in the ark the testimony that I shall give to you.
25.22: And I shall have a meeting with you there, and I shall speak with you from over the Mercy Seat from between the two Cherubim that are over the Ark of the Testimony, everything that I command you about the children of Israel.
25.23: And make a table of the wood of the box tree, two cubits its length, and a cubit its width, and a cubit and a half its height.
25.24: And overlay it in pure gold and make for it a crown of gold encircling.
25.25: And make for it a rim that may be a handbreadth high encircling and make a crown of gold encircling on the rim.
25.26: And make for it four rings of gold and you shall make four rings of gold on its four corners over its four feet.
25.27: Against its rim its rings shall be a place for the poles to carry the table.
25.28: And make poles of wood of the box tree and overlay them in gold, by which the table is to be carried.
25.29: And make dishes and ladles and vessels and bowls into which things are poured; of pure gold you shall make them.
25.30: And you will put on the table the bread of The Faces before me constantly.
25.31: And make a lamp stand of pure gold; you shall make the menorah of smelting; its base and its branches and its bowls and its apples and its lilies shall be of it.
25.32: And six branches that will come out from its sides: three branches from one side of the menorah and three branches from its other side:
25.33: Three bowls are joined on one branch and the apples and lilies and three bowls joined on another branch, and the apples and the lilies in this way on six branches will come out from the lamp stand.
25.34: And on the Menorah shall be four bowls and apples and lilies.
25.35: An apple under two branches of it, and an apple under another two branches of it, and an apple under another two branches of it, so it shall be with the six branches that come out from the lamp stand.
25.36: And the apples and the branches of it shall be all of one smelting of pure gold.
25.37: And make its seven lamps and light its lamps that they will be giving light against its face.
25.38: And make its snuffers and its bases of pure gold.
25.39: From a talent of pure gold you shall make it and all these implements.
25.40: And see and make it in this likeness that I show to you in the mountain.

26.1: And for the Tabernacle you shall make ten curtains of fine woven white linen, blue fringes and purple and dye of scarlet; you shall make Cherubim, the work of a craftsman.
26.2: The length of one curtain is twenty and eight cubits, and its width, four cubits; all curtains have the one measure of the one curtain.
26.3: Five curtains will be joined one to one, and five curtains will be joined one to one.
26.4: And make curtain rings of blue fringes on the edge of one curtain that are joined on its side, and thus you shall make on the side of the curtain from the other side that is joined.
26.5: Fifty rings you shall make on the edge of one curtain and fifty rings you shall make on the other edge of the curtain in the other coupling, and they shall be upright rings, one against one.
26.6: And make fifty clasps of gold and join one curtain on another with a clasp, and the Tabernacle will be one.
26.7: And make a curtain of hair for a covering of the Tabernacle; eleven curtains you shall make them.
26.8: The length of one curtain of them, thirty cubits, and its width four cubits, the one measure of one curtain is for all these eleven curtains.
26.9: And join five curtains as one, and six curtains as one, and fold the sixth curtain against the face of the Tabernacle.
26.10: And make fifty rings on the edge of one curtain from the side that is joined and fifty rings on the edge of a curtain in joining another.
26.11: And make fifty clasps of brass and bring the clasps into the rings and join the Tabernacle and it will be one.
26.12: And what is left of the curtains of the Tabernacle, half of a curtain remaining, you shall hang to the back of the Tabernacle.
26.13: And a cubit from one side and a cubit from the other side remaining in the length of the curtains of the Tabernacle shall be hanging over the side of the Tabernacle, from this side and from that, for its covering.
26.14: And make a cover for the Tabernacle, skins of rams that are dyed red, skins of rams of sky blue from above.
26.15: And make boards for the Tabernacle of the wood of box tree standing.
26.16: Ten cubits the length of one board and a cubit and half the width of one board.
26.17: And two sockets to one upright board, one against one, in this way you shall make all the boards of the Tabernacle.
26.18: And make the boards for the Tabernacle, twenty boards for the side of the wind of the south.
26.19: And forty sockets of silver you shall make under twenty boards, two sockets under one board for its two hinges and two sockets under another board for its two hinges.
26.20: And for the other side of the Tabernacle from the wind of the north, twenty boards:
26.21: And forty sockets of silver, two sockets under one board and two sockets under another board.
26.22: And from the outside of the Tabernacle from the west make six boards.
26.23: And two boards you shall make for the corners of the Tabernacle from their outer sides.
26.24: That they will be equal from the bottom and they shall be coupled together on its top on one ring handle, in this way to both sockets, they shall be for two corners.
26.25: And there shall be eight boards and their sixteen sockets of silver, two sockets under one board and two sockets under another board.
26.26: And make the bars from the wood of the box tree, five for the boards of one side of the Tabernacle,
26.27: And five bars for the boards of the other side of the Tabernacle, and five bars for the boards of the other side at the outside of the Tabernacle on the west.
26.28: And pass the middle bars between the boards from this side to that.
26.29: And overlay the boards in gold, and make the rings of gold the place for the bars and overlay the bars in gold.
26.30: And erect the Tabernacle rightly as I showed you in the mountain.
26.31: And make a covering of fringes and purple and dye of scarlet and fine woven white linen; make a Cherub, the work of a craftsman:
26.32: And place it on four pillars of boxwood overlaid in gold and their nails of gold on four sockets of silver.
26.33: And put a covering under the boards and bring there the ark of the Testimony inside the covering and you shall spread out for you a covering between the Holy and between The Holy of Holies.
26.34: And you shall put the Mercy Seat on the ark of the Testimony in the Holy of Holies.
26.35: And you shall put the table outside of the covering and the menorahs opposite the table on the south side of the Tabernacle, and the table you shall put on the north side.
26.36: And make a covering for the door of the Tabernacle, the blue fringes and purple and dye of scarlet and fine woven white linen, the work of embroidery.
26.37: And make for the coverings five pillars of boxwood and overlay them in gold and their nails of gold and make for them five sockets of brass.

27.1: And make the altar of the wood of the box tree, five cubits its length and five cubits its width; the altar shall be square and its height three cubits.
27.2: And make its horns; its horns will be on the four corners of it, and overlay it with brass.
27.3: And make its pots for its ministry and its cauldrons, and its hanging pots, and its forks, and its censers, and all its implements make of brass.
27.4: And make a grate as the work of a network of brass and make four rings of brass over the grate, over its four sides.
27.5: Put it under the outside of the altar underneath, and the grate shall be unto the middle of the altar.
27.6: And make poles for the altar, poles of the wood of box tree and overlay them with brass.
27.7: And put poles in the rings and they shall be on two sides of the altar when they carry it.
27.8: Hollow with boards you shall make it, as I showed you in the mountain, in this way they shall do.
27.9: And make a courtyard for the Tabernacle on the side of the south wind, the curtain of the courtyard of fine woven white linen, a hundred cubits the length of one curtain.
27.10: Its pillars are twenty and their sockets of brass twenty, and the nails of the pillars and their overlay of silver.
